description: From Latin praecipitatus, from praecipitō (“throw down, hurl down, throw headlong”), from praeceps (“head foremost, headlong”), from prae (“before”) + caput (“head”). Its English equivalent is probably analysable as precipice +‎ -ate.

adjectives.description: Verb: Adjective: common but often proscribed:
precipitate (comparative more precipitate, superlative most precipitate)

entries.meaning: With a hasty impulse; hurried; headstrong.
examples: Synonyms: hotheaded, impetuous, rash; see also Thesaurus:reckless

entries.meaning: Moving with excessive speed or haste; overly hasty.
examples: The king was too precipitate in declaring war.
Synonyms: abrupt, precipitous, subitaneous; see also Thesaurus:sudden

verbs.description: Verb: Adjective: common but often proscribed:
precipitate (third-person singular simple present precipitates, present participle precipitating, simple past and past participle precipitated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make something happen suddenly and quickly.
examples: Synonyms: advance, accelerate, hasten, speed up
to precipitate a journey, or a conflict

entries.meaning: (transitive) To throw an object or person from a great height.
examples: Synonyms: throw, fling, cast; see also Thesaurus:throw

entries.meaning: (transitive) To send violently into a certain state or condition.
examples: we were precipitated into a conflict

entries.meaning: (intransitive, chemistry) To come out of a liquid solution into solid form.
examples: Adding the acid will cause the salt to precipitate.

entries.meaning: (transitive, chemistry) To separate a substance out of a liquid solution into solid form.
(intransitive, meteorology) To have water in the air fall to the ground, for example as rain, snow, sleet, or hail; be deposited as condensed droplets.
examples: It will precipitate tomorrow, but we don't know whether as rain or snow.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause (water in the air) to condense or fall to the ground.
examples: The light vapour of the preceding evening had been precipitated by the cold.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To act too hastily; to be precipitous.

description: From New Latin praecipitatum. Doublet of precipitato.

entries.meaning: a product resulting from a process, event, or course of action
(chemistry) a solid that exits the liquid phase of a solution
